title.hi: The Good and Evil Angels (Private Collection)

objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the first one printed in 1795. The second impression in that printing session is The Good and Evil Angels in the Tate Collection (Butlin 323).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Private Collection
provenance.note: By inheritance to Mrs. Blake; by bequest to Frederick Tatham; sold Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 182 (£1.16s. to the dealer Toovey); Henry Cunliffe, probably acquired in or shortly after 1862; sold Sotheby's, 11 May 1895, lot 104 (£8.8s. to the dealer Frank Sabin); Mrs. William Payne Whitney (nee Helen Julia Hay) by 1919; by inheritance in 1944 to John Hay Whitney; by inheritance in 1982 to Mrs. John Hay Whitney (nee Betsey Maria Cushing); by bequest to the Greentree Foundation, 1998; sold Sotheby's New York, 5 May 2004, lot 5 ($3,928,000 to an anonymous private collector).

desc.objtitle: The Good and Evil Angels (Private Collection), object 1 (Butlin 324)

objnote.p: The textual context of the earliest version of "The Good and Evil Angels," on plate 4 of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell (1790), offers some insight into its meaning. On plate 3 of The Marriage, Blake introduces the "contraries...the religious call Good & Evil" (Erdman page 34). We can identify the figure on the left in the color printed drawing as the "Evil" angel, shackled on his left ankle and rising before flames. On the right, holding a child apparently struggling to be free, is the "Good" angel. On plate 4 of The Marriage, the "voice of the Devil" continues to explore the binary oppositions of fallen vision and claims that the religious identify "Evil" with "Energy" and "the Body," and the "Good" with "Reason" and the "Soul" (Erdman page 34). In his comments that follow, the Devil does not so much reverse this equation as deny the linked differences themselves, stating that the body is an aspect of soul. The color print may also indicate the fall into the errors of the good/evil, body/soul, energy/reason dualities. The child may thus represent humanity caught between these contending oppositions.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two male angels representing good and evil occupy opposite sides of the design. The figure on the left, the evil angel, hovers before large flames. He leans forward with arms extended horizontally, palms down and fingers slightly spread. He may be looking, and reaching with his left hand, toward the child held by the other adult figure. His right leg is extended backwards; a shackle and chain bind his left ankle to the earth below. The evil angel is nude and muscular, with clearly indicated genitals; he has short, slightly flame-like hair. His face, particularly his forehead, is wrinkled, possibly with despair or anger rather than age. On the right, the good angel, a nude, muscular male figure with medium length, flame-like hair, hovers over a shoreline against the backdrop of a rising or setting sun, and holds a child in his arms. The good angel faces forward with his left leg extended backward, but looks to the left, towards the evil angel, with his mouth open in an expression of fear (or at least serious concern). His arms are bent at the elbows, and his right hand grasps the child, while the left holds (or at least touches) the side of the child’s torso. The good angel may be moving the child to the right, out of the reach of the evil angel. The child (apparently male) in the arms of the good angel faces away from the viewer, but with his head turned to left profile and with arms raised vertically, palms out and fingers spread; his left leg is extended. He appears to be looking at the evil angel. He has short, curly hair and a muscular body; his raised left arm covers his mouth. It is difficult to determine his facial expression, but his posture and gestures suggest fear of the evil angel and an attempt to flee from him.

component.illusobjdesc: The male evil angel hovers on the left before large flames. He leans forward with his upper body nearly horizontal. His arms are outstretched horizontally with palms down and thumbs spread away from the fingers. He may be looking, and reaching with his left hand, toward the child held by the angel on the right. His lips may be slightly parted. The evil angel's right leg is extended backward; a shackle that appears to be chained to the ground binds his left ankle. The evil angel is nude and muscular, with genitals clearly delineated; he has short, slightly flame-like hair. His face, particularly his forehead, is wrinkled, perhaps with despair or anger rather than age. He may be hovering, rising, or struggling against the chain.
A shackle, apparently chained to the ground, binds the left ankle of the evil angel.

The evil angel hovers before several large flames that seem to originate from the left side of the design and burn diagonally towards the right. Smoke may darken the sky above the flames, which may also cast a shadow on the ground below. The right side of the evil angel's torso is also darkened by a shadow.

The good angel on the right, a nude, muscular male figure with medium length, flame-like hair, hovers (or strides forward and to the left) over a shore against the backdrop of a rising or setting sun. He holds a child in his arms. The good angel faces forward with his left leg bent slightly at the knee and extended backward, but looks to the left, towards the evil angel, with his mouth slightly open in an expression of fear (or at least serious concern). His feet are prominent; his arms are bent at the elbows and his right hand grasps the child’s buttocks, while the left holds (or at least touches) the side of the child’s torso. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread. The good angel may be attempting to move the child beyond the reach of the evil angel.

The good angel holds a muscular male child with short, curly hair. The child’s body faces away from the viewer, but his head is turned towards the left; he may be looking towards the evil angel. His raised left arm covers his mouth; it is difficult to determine his facial expression. His posture, with arms raised vertically, palms out, with fingers spread and legs extended, expresses fear. He is probably trying to flee from the evil angel, and perhaps also from the grasp of the good angel holding him.

The good angel hovers before a sea bordered in the foreground by a shore and in the background by a horizon with a rising or setting sun. White-capped waves strike the apparently sandy shore. A glow of radiance surround the sun. There may be clouds, illuminated by the sun, in the sky on both sides of the good angel and child.
Olive green coloring on the ground or sand hints at low-growing vegetation, such as grass, lichens, or moss.
